results.title: Snow warning extended in Surrey and some could be 'cut off'
results.body:
A yellow weather warning for snow and ice issued by forecasters at the Met Office has been extended as cold weather is set to continue across the UK. This now coincides with a level three cold weather alert put in place by the government's UKHSA which lasts until midnight on Thursday (March 9).

The Met Office yellow warning now runs from midnight on Wednesday (March 8) through until 9am on Thursday (March 9). It comes as spells of snow on Wednesday are expected to cause disruption into Thursday morning. A 13-hour snow and ice alert was first issued in Surrey at 9pm on Monday (March 6).

Snow had yet to fall in the county at the time of publication, with Surrey weather forecaster Ian Currie giving an explanation to SurreyLive as to why. He also made a new prediction for when snow could fall this week.

Residents in the county and people travelling through have been warned of possible travel delays and the stranding of some vehicles and passengers. Public transport may also be cancelled as well as road closures. The Met Office has warned rural communities may become cut off and power cuts could occur.

READ MORE: All the roads in Surrey prioritised by gritters amid snow warning

A spokesperson for the forecaster spoke of the need to extend the warning and said: "Warning extended further north across a larger part of southern England and East Anglia, with the likelihood of impacts increased, and ice included as part of the warning. Warning has also been extended into Thursday, primarily to include residual ice impacts that may persist into the morning travel period."

The yellow warning was issued this week due to an area of rain, sleet, and snow that is expected to develop over southwest England on Tuesday (March 7) and which will move east overnight and into Wednesday (March 8). It is thought this will begin to clear mid-morning but further sleet and snow are again likely in the afternoon and evening.

The snow is expected to clear on Wednesday night but clear skies will result in ice on untreated surfaces. This will then linger into Thursday morning (March 9) and continue to impact travel.

results.title: Latest maps show when massive wall of snow could finally fall over London
results.body:
Despite a yellow weather warning for snow and ice in London from the Met Office for the start of the week, there has been no snow in sight. Though a relief for some, this is also disappointing for many.

The yellow warning was originally in play until 10am today (Tuesday, March 7) across London, but it has now been extended further during tomorrow and Thursday. Even through there isn't any snow, the warning is in place to keep people safe during adverse conditions and asks people to be mindful that some roads and railways likely to be affected with longer journey times by road, bus and train services.

In a recent forecast WX Charts, an independent forecaster, is predicting proper snow over the city from the evening of March 13 until the next day. However, the Met Office forecast predicts rainfall on and temperatures of 13 degrees on this day.

READ NEXT: Met Office reveals exact date snow set to fall on capital

Today's weather forecast remains at 5 degrees, with night time temperatures staying just above freezing conditions. There will be spells of rain throughout the day too.

London's weather forecast for the rest of the week can be found below.

Today

A cold start with rain and snow showers making slow progress southwards, clearing by the evening. Snow most likely over higher ground, but possible to lower levels. Cloudier in the south, with temperatures falling in the north under clearing skies. Maximum temperature 4 °C.

Tonight

A cold night with patchy frost and icy stretches, most likely in the north. Dry to start, before further sleet and light snow likely for southern counties. Minimum temperature -1 °C.

Wednesday

Maps show snow being dumped on London in the early hours of Wednesday morning. Further snow likely later into the evening, with some heavier bursts possible at times. Maximum temperature 4 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday

Staying cold with frosts overnight. Strong winds, and a risk of more rain and snow, to occur on Thursday and Friday. Saturday daytime looking drier and brighter.

results.title: Cornwall snow forecast: Where Met Office says it could fall
results.body:
Snow is expected to fall on Cornwall overnight as temperatures plunge, says the Met Office. The needle will fall close to freezing on higher ground, with a "feels like" temperature of -3C.

Tomorrow (March 8) and Thursday will see the county, as well as other areas of the Westcountry, plunge into a yellow Met Office weather warning for snow and ice.

Most of it looks set to fall on the higher areas of the south west. For Cornwall those living close to the River Tamar are more likely to wake up to signs that Jack Frost has visited and across the border in Devon, Dartmoor and Exmoor and their native towns and villages will likely experience the brunt of the weather.

READ MORE: Northern Lights dazzle Cornwall sky with stunning display

The chances of snow are less likely for those living south west of Bodmin but weather conditions may still be treacherous, and there could be some disruption for those planning on travelling by train or car out of the county. Snow is expected to fall in areas of Devon, Somerset, and Dorset.

Below are the main where snow has been predicted to fall for tomorrow in Cornwall:

Bodmin

The Met Office has forecasted Bodmin to receive a small amount of sleet between 2am and 3am, which then turns to light rain by 4am.

Clouds and spatterings of rain will fall through the morning until 11am, which then sees light rain turn heavy to last throughout the afternoon and into the early evening.

Camelford

Camelford has been predicted sleet for 1am, which turns briefly to heavy snow at 2am. After this, the Met Office says light snow will fall from around 3am until 7am, so those in the area may well open their curtains to a snowy winter's day.

Another burst of light snow has been predicted to fall at around 10am, but with rain and 3C-4C weather predicted for the afternoon it's not likely that the snow will last.

Liskeard

The town of Liskeard is predicted to have sleet starting at around 2am tomorrow morning which will last for approximately 2 hours. Then, from 5am until 7am, light snow has been predicted for the area with an accompanying temperature of a brisk 2C, which means those heading out early in their cars may experience some snowfall.

As such, extra precautions are advised to avoid accidents on the roads. The rest of the morning sees rain which gradually gets heavier throughout the day.

South West region weather forecast for the week ahead Today:

Cloudy on Tuesday with outbreaks of rain and sleet, perhaps some snow, especially over hills. This gradually moves its way southwards, turning patchier and lighter though staying rather cloudy. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 7 °C.

Tonight:

Outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow likely to spread northeastwards overnight, with some lying snow likely by dawn, especially over higher ground. Cold with the risk of icy patches. Minimum temperature -1 °C.

Wednesday:

Mostly cloudy with further outbreaks of mainly light rain, sleet, or snow during the morning. Briefly turning drier before rain or snow returns later with strengthening winds. Maximum temperature 6 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday:

Turning milder later in the week though staying unsettled with further rain at times and often rather windy, with some strong winds on Friday. A slight improvement on Saturday.

results.title: Met Office extends snow warning in South West
results.body:
An urgent weather warning for snow covering the South West has been extended by a further nine hours. The Exeter-based Met Office initially issued the alert yesterday (March 6) with most of the region and parts of southern England and Wales covered on Wednesday (March 8).

The warning was just for snow and was put in place for a 24-hour period starting at midnight. However, following an update to forecasts, the Met Office has now made changes to the warning, which now includes ice.

Other alterations include the area covered by the warning being extended across more of southern England all the way to East Anglia. The timings have also been changed with the warning set to remain in place until 9am on Thursday (March 9).

Read more:Kirstie Allsopp slams Prince Harry's 'privileged' drugs confession

In its update, the Met Office said: "Warning extended further north across a larger part of southern England and East Anglia, with the likelihood of impacts increased, and ice included as part of the warning. Warning has also been extended into Thursday, primarily to include residual ice impacts that may persist into the morning travel period."

The warning itself states: "Spells of snow on Wednesday may cause travel disruption during Wednesday into Thursday morning."

Met Office forecasters have said the following can be expected during the warning period:

Possible travel delays on roads stranding some vehicles and passengers. Bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times possible. Some rural communities could become temporarily cut off. Power cuts may occur and other services may be temporarily affected. Untreated pavements and cycle paths might be impassable with a chance of injuries from slips and falls on snow-covered or icy surfaces. Met Office five-day weather forecast for the South West Today

Cloudy on Tuesday with outbreaks of rain and sleet, perhaps some snow, especially over hills. This gradually moves its way southwards, turning patchier and lighter though staying rather cloudy. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 7 °C.

Tonight

Outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow likely to spread northeastwards overnight, with some lying snow likely by dawn, especially over higher ground. Cold with the risk of icy patches. Minimum temperature -1 °C.

Tomorrow

Mostly cloudy with further outbreaks of mainly light rain, sleet, or snow during the morning. Briefly turning drier before rain or snow returns later with strengthening winds. Maximum temperature 6 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday

Turning milder later in the week though staying unsettled with further rain at times and often rather windy, with some strong winds on Friday. A slight improvement on Saturday.

results.title: Weather forecaster explains why we didn't see snow in Surrey
results.body:
A weather forecaster said those disappointed by the lack of snow in Surrey on Tuesday (March 7) should keep their eyes peeled. Surrey was issued with a 13-hour snow warning by the Met Office and many were hoping to wake up to see it as predicted. Instead, despite remaining very cold, the white stuff has not fallen just yet.

But Ian Currie, a broadcaster and a member of the Royal Meteorological Society, said people should not lose hope yet. Although he had received reports of snow in some higher areas of the county, he said it was most likely to fall across the rest of Surrey on Wednesday (March 8).

"The weather system affecting us at the moment is going to return with renewed bursts of precipitation," Mr Currie said. "I think that it could provide snow and sleet more generally in Surrey and Sussex tomorrow.

READ MORE:Surrey under 13 hour snow warning with some people told to stock up on food

"There's very mild air to the south but very cold air to the north and tomorrow we'll be at the boundary of that which will give the precipitation and perhaps 2cm to 3cm of snow. It's going to be quite changeable.

"March can have more snow and sleet than the winter. The Arctic is at its coldest and when you do get cold air bursting out it can produce snow. There have been many examples of snowstorms in March, on this date in 1891 a person was buried in a 15-foot snowdrift near Dorking and died."

Mr Currie, who correctly predicted the famous October 1987 storm, also had his say on the Met Office weather warnings with some saying they fail to predict the snow or extreme weather as promised. He said weather systems were tricky to predict but the alert had correctly guessed snow would fall in other areas such as Oxfordshire and Suffolk.

He added: "What they're saying is the potential and this potential is a developing situation. What they're really saying is, 'keep abreast of the forecast, there is a potential situation now for snow and cold weather'.

"Snow is very fickle, [it's hard to say] precisely where it will occur. At least people are aware and they're not caught out, if they said nothing and there's heavy snow people would be saying 'nobody told us'."

results.title: Met Office issue UK-wide snow warning as Brits set to freeze later this week
results.body:
Met Office yellow warnings have been issued to cover the entire UK on Thursday, with snow and ice expected to hit the country, with up to 10cm of snow expected in some parts of the country

The Met Office has issued a UK-wide snow warning, with Brits set to freeze this week under blankets of snow and ice.

Yellow weather warnings were initially posted for Tuesday, March 7 and Wednesday, March 8, but have since been updated to include the rest of the week.

Snow and ice will stretch across the UK, hitting all four members and leaving few parts of the country free of whirlwind snowstorms and sheets of ice.

READ MORE: Met Office's major snow update with 'Arctic polar vortex' set to blast Britain

Thursday morning in particular is set for icy surfaces, while some parts of the country will have to deal with heavy bouts of snow that could see 5 to 10cm of snowfall.

Chances of "long delays" to travel as well as road blockages and "interruptions to power supplies and other services" including gas and water were reported by a Met Office weather warning.

Friday proved no better as Met Office officials confirmed a yellow weather warning for most of the UK at the end of the working week too.

They warned that "snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday", which stretches across almost the entire United Kingdom.

A statement added: "In addition, there is potential for strong winds, which may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow."

An impact map listed on the official Met Office website showed the yellow warnings of snow and ice for Thursday would hit the likes of London, Newcastle and cover much of Scotland.

Friday saw the yellow warning updated, with residents of Inverness, Scotland, all the way down to Nottingham set to be affected by the snow and ice warning.

Met Office officials made it clear that Thursday's weather warning could have knock-on effects to those in areas across the UK the following day.

They said: "Snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday and Friday as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK."

For the latest weather updates and breaking news stories from the UK and across the globe, sign up for our newsletter by clicking here.

results.title: UK Met Office snow map shows exact time it'll hit Birmingham
results.body:
A snow map from the Met Office detailing its snow and ice warnings shows the exact hour it will hit Birmingham. The West Midlands is in the grip of a snow and ice warning on Tuesday March 7.

There are weather warnings acrosss four days this week - from Tuesday to Friday March 10. In its warning, forecasters say: "Frequent snow showers will continue, causing further disruption in places."

A snow and ice warning affected Scotland and north east England will last until 10am tomorrow. As well as that warning, which lasts til Wednesday, another alert will take hold in the south west of England.

READ MORE Met Office shares exact date -10C snow blast ends and UK finally warms up

"Spells of snow on Wednesday may cause travel disruption during Wednesday into Thursday morning," the Met Office advises. Possible travel delays on roads stranding some vehicles and passengers.

Bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times possible. Some rural communities could become temporarily cut off. Power cuts may occur and other services may be temporarily affected.

Untreated pavements and cycle paths might be impassable with a chance of injuries from slips and falls on snow-covered or icy surfaces. Into Thursday and the snow and ice warning in the north turns into a pure snow warning.

It lasts from 3am Thursday to 6pm on Friday. Snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday and Friday as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK. Parts of Northern Ireland, north Wales and northern England are currently expected to see the worst of the conditions on Thursday, with parts of Scotland and northern England then seeing the heaviest snow on Friday.

Event totals could bring 5 to 10 cm of snow to many locations, even at low elevations, with potentially 15 to 20 cm accumulating across the northern portion of the warning area. In addition, there is potential for strong winds, which may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow.

results.title: Met Office issues another snow warning for Herefordshire
results.body:
Some parts of England could see up to 10 centimetres of snow fall in a few hours on Wednesday, with the warning in force from midnight until 9am on Thursday.

Covering Herefordshire, Worcestershire, South Wales and southern England, the weather warning tells people there will be spells of snow on Wednesday may cause travel disruption during Wednesday into Thursday morning.

The county, which also had a yellow weather warning for Monday and Tuesday, should see around one to three centimetres of snow.

"An area of rain, sleet and snow is expected to develop over southwest England during Tuesday evening and move east during early Wednesday before clearing mid-morning," Met Office forecasters said.

"Whilst drier conditions may develop for a time through the middle of the day, a further spell of sleet and snow is likely to develop during the afternoon and move east into the evening.

"There remains significant uncertainty in how far north snow develops as well as whether accumulations are focused mainly over higher ground.

"At this stage, the focus for the higher snow accumulations is across England south of the M4 during later Wednesday where there is a chance that some places could see 5-10 cm falling in a few hours."

The Met Office says this is what people should expect:

The Met Office also said: "Earlier in the day and across the wider warning area, accumulations are expected to be lower, typically 1-3 cm.

"As snow clears on Wednesday night, clearing skies will result in ice developing on untreated surfaces with impacts lingering into Thursday morning."

results.title: Met Office weather maps show when heavy snow will hit Berkshire
results.body:
A 33-hour weather warning has been implemented by the Met Office

A new Met Office weather map shows when snow is most likely to hit Berkshire. Despite spring being not too far away, another spell of cold weather could bring snow and sleet to large parts of the UK.

The Met Office has issued various weather warnings, most of those warning of snow and ice, in recent days. A recently issued warning for snow and ice has been expanded to cover all of Berkshire and will come into force at midnight tonight (March 8).

The warning will remain in effect until 9am on Thursday morning (March 9) and will bring some disruption. Whilst the warning is in place for 33 hours, much of the snowfall is due to arrive over a short period on Wednesday evening, according to the Met Office map.

READ MORE: M4, A404(M) and A34 road closures this week as National Highways issues diversions

The weather map suggests that much of Tuesday will be relatively dry in Berkshire with the odd damp spell in the early afternoon. Whilst much of southern England will see a wet start to Wednesday, it will be mostly dry in Berkshire with the wet and wild conditions not forecast until mid-afternoon.

By 3pm there could be some heavy rain and possible hail lasting until around 6pm at which point the snow and sleet will begin arriving. By 8pm on Wednesday, almost all of Berkshire could be experiencing snowfall, according to the Met Office map, which will last for around an hour before turning into rain - Thursday morning may be damp but no further snow is expected.

In its warning, the Met Office has said: "An area of rain, sleet and snow is expected to develop over southwest England during Tuesday evening and move east during early Wednesday before clearing mid-morning. Whilst drier conditions may develop for a time through the middle of the day, a further spell of sleet and snow is likely to develop during the afternoon and move east into the evening.

"There remains significant uncertainty in how far north snow develops as well as whether accumulations are focused mainly over higher ground. At this stage, the focus for the higher snow accumulations is across England south of the M4 during later Wednesday where there is a chance that some places could see 5-10 cm falling in a few hours.

"Earlier in the day and across the wider warning area, accumulations are expected to be lower, typically 1-3 cm. As snow clears on Wednesday night, clearing skies will result in ice developing on untreated surfaces with impacts lingering into Thursday morning."

A more recent update to the warning reads: "Warning extended further north across a larger part of southern England and East Anglia, with the likelihood of impacts increased, and ice included as part of the warning. The warning has also been extended into Thursday, primarily to include residual ice impacts that may persist into the morning travel period."

The Met Office has warned that travel networks, including cars, bus and train services, could be affected by the snow and ice with journey times expected to be longer than usual. If the snow is severe, there could also be some road closures and instances of people getting stranded or villages cut off.

Pedestrians should take care when outside as untreated pavements or cycle paths could become slippery, increasing the risk of injuries. Power cuts and loss of other important services is possible.

results.title: When it's expected to snow again in the North East, according to weather experts
results.body:
There were some picture-postcard scenes across the North East on Tuesday morning, with many parts of the region blanketed by snow.

Temperatures dropped overnight and warnings were put in place of possible disruption to road, rail and air travel. There were also two yellow weather warnings from the Met Office, urging people to take care outdoors.

An alert for snow and ice is in place until 10am on Wednesday. and another one for snow runs from 3am on Thursday to 6pm on Friday. While there was no more snow predicted for the rest of Tuesday, forecasters expected some white stuff to come our way in the coming days.

Read More: Hour-by-hour weather forecast as North East hit by snow with Met Office warnings in place

According to the Met Office, it is going to remain "cold this week, with snow showers and widespread frosts". Some scattered snow showers are possible in some areas on Wednesday but most of the snow will come on Thursday and Friday.

At the time of writing, the forecast showed sleet in Newcastle at around 6pm on Thursday, 3am on Friday morning, then again at 3pm that day, with rain in between those times. Light snow showers are shown at 6pm on Friday.

In Hexham, Northumberland, light snow is expected from midday onwards on Thursday, turning heavy from around 6pm and continuing through the night. The heavy snowfall will stay till 9am on Friday.

Over in Consett, County Durham, light snowfall will begin at around midday on Thursday, which is expected to turn heavy from 6pm. The forecast for the area shows snow until 3pm on Friday, heavier in the morning and lighter by the afternoon.

Meanwhile, in Whitley Bay, North Tyneside, there could be light snow in the early hours of Thursday and some between 9am and midday. Below, is the five-day weather forecast for the whole of the North East.

North East weather forecast

Tuesday:

A very cold start with a widespread frost and scattered snow showers, mostly along exposed windward coasts. Showers easing off through the afternoon with cloud clearing to give another very cold night, with widespread frost and some icy patches forming. Maximum temperature 4°C.

Tuesday night:

A very cold night with a severe frost, and icy patches in places still damp from daytime showers. The odd snow shower may affect exposed windward coasts at times. Minimum temperature -4°C.

Wednesday:

A bright, cold, and frosty start with scattered snow showers along coastlines. Cloudier through the afternoon with the odd snow shower pushing inland at times. Maximum temperature 3°C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday:

Staying cold with widespread frosts overnight. Risk of disruptive snow and strong winds to occur on Thursday and Friday. Saturday looking drier and brighter.

Read Next:

Second yellow weather warning issued for snow across the North East on Thursday and Friday

results.title: Met Office Issues Snow Weather Warning As Tonight Could Be The Coldest Evening Of The Year
results.body:
Double up on the duvets and wear your fluffiest jumper tonight as it could be the coldest night of the year.

The Met Office has announced that temperatures could plummet to minus 15C in some sheltered Scottish glens and have also issued weather warnings for snow and ice across the UK.

Currently, the lowest temperature that has been recorded in the UK this year is minus 10.4C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit near Inverness in the Highlands in the early hours of January 19.

Temperatures are set to drop almost six degrees below their coldest last March, when they reached minus 9.1C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire.

Weather warnings for snow and ice are in place across all four nations of the UK and more are expected to be issued as Arctic air sweeps across the country.

A yellow weather warning for snow and ice will be in place for London, the Thames Valley, East Anglia, parts of the Midlands, and South Wales from 9pm on Monday night until 10am on Tuesday.

The same warning will be in place in Northern Ireland at the same time.

A yellow weather warning for snow and ice is already in place in much of Northern and Eastern Scotland and North East England.

Snow began falling in Northern Scotland on Monday afternoon. More than 20cm of it could accumulate over high ground in Scotland and more than 5cm is likely to accumulate at lower levels in the north-east of the UK.

The Met Office said snow will move from the south to the north of the UK as mild air from the south-west meets cold air.

Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge said temperatures could drop to minus 1C in Manchester and 2C in London on Monday night.

"Temperatures will be much, much colder than we would expect at this time of year," Madge says.

"The pattern will set in for some time. We have got this feed of cold air coming in from a much higher latitude. "We expect these conditions to remain in place until at least next weekend and possibly longer because sometimes these conditions can be quite stubborn and not easily subject to change."

People are at risk of slipping and falling on icy patches of untreated roads, pavements, and paths while some rural communities could become cut off from the power grid.

"Freezing conditions bring so many hazards such as snow and ice. Take every possible step to understand your journey in advance and allow lots of extra time when travelling to prepare for the unexpected," Dale Hipkiss, National Network Manager at National Highways, said.

results.title: Met Office extends snow and ice weather warning for Newport and Gwent
results.body:
The Met Office has extended the yellow weather warning for South Wales including Newport and Gwent.

The yellow weather warning has been extended for the next two days as spells of snow and ice look set to cause travel disruptions on Wednesday and Thursday mornings.

It covers the entire South Wales area including Newport, Monmouthshire, Caerphilly, Torfaen, and Blaenau Gwent.

The original warning came into force at 9pm last night and was in place until 10am today.

The extended warnings are in place from midnight until 9am tomorrow and the same time period on Thursday, March 9.

The Met Office said the extended yellow weather warnings were due to snow forecast for tomorrow and Thursday mornings.

The warning said people could expect possible travel delays with the risk of some vehicles and passengers being left stranded.

The yellow weather warning issued for mid-south Wales has been extended until Thursday. (Image: The Met Office)

The Met Office added: "Bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times possible.

"Some rural communities could become temporarily cut off, power cuts may occur and other services may be temporarily affected.

"Untreated pavements and cycle paths might be impassable with a chance of injuries from slips and falls on snow-covered or icy surfaces."

A Met Office spokesperson explained the reason for the extended weather warnings.

The spokesperson said: "The warning has been extended further north across a larger part of southern England and East Anglia, with the likelihood of impacts increased, and ice included as part of the warning.

"Warning has also been extended into Thursday, primarily to include residual ice impacts that may persist into the morning travel period."

The Met Office said yesterday the weather band that was set to hit Wales could bring 1 to 2cm of snow to some areas.

A Met Office spokesperson said: "A band of rain will edge southwards through the course of Monday evening and early Tuesday, this rain turning to snow on hills and perhaps to lower levels in places.

"Many areas will see little or no accumulations of snow, but 1 to 2 cm could settle in some spots, most likely over high ground and southern parts of the warning area.

"The rain and snow is then expected to turn light and patchy as it slowly clears southern England on Tuesday. As skies clear overnight, ice is also likely to form readily on untreated surfaces."

The yellow weather warning is set to come into force at midnight tonight. (Image: PA)

This is every region of Wales that could see snow as the Met Office issues a yellow weather warning:

results.title: Heavy snow alert issued for Scotland with warnings of 40cm drifts
results.body:
The Met Office has warned that parts of Scotland may see as much as 40cm of snow later this week.

A yellow alert for snow has been issued for the entire country south of Inverness, stretching from Jura in the west to Peterhead in the north east.

The national weather service predicts that heavy snow has the potential to cause "significant disruption" on Thursday and Friday.

The warning comes into force at 3am on Thursday and extends through to 6pm on Friday, with prts of Scotland set to see the heaviest snow fall on Friday.

READ MORE: Green deposit return scheme will alter competitive landscape across Scotland

As much as 30-40cm of snow could be set to fall on parts of the Southern Uplands, the Central Belt and the southern Highlands, with potentially 15-20cm accumulation across northern areas. Other areas, even at low elevations, could see between 5-10 cm of snow, the warning notes.

Scotland could also be met with blizzard conditions and drifting of lying slow given the potential for strong winds.

The warning reads: Snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday and Friday as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK. Parts of Northern Ireland, north Wales and northern England are currently expected to see the worst of the conditions on Thursday, with parts of Scotland and northern England then seeing the heaviest snow on Friday.

"Event totals could bring 5 to 10 cm of snow to many locations, even at low elevations, with potentially 15 to 20 cm accumulating across the northern portion of the warning area. Higher elevations of the North Pennines, Southern Uplands, higher parts of the Central Belt and the southern Highlands may see as much as 30 to 40 cm of snow in places.

"In addition, there is potential for strong winds, which may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow.

The Met Office said there is a small chance that "long delays and cancellations on bus, rail and air travel could occur, alongside "long interruptions to power supplies and other services, such as gas, water, telephone and mobile phone coverage" may occur.

There is also a slight chance that roads may become blocked by deep snow, with many stranded vehicles and passengers and a small chance that "communities could be cut off for several days", it added.

results.title: Weather warning extended across Sussex as 'Arctic blast' heads towards Britain
results.body:
A weather warning for snow and ice has been extended as an Arctic blast heads towards the UK.

Spells of snow on Wednesday may cause travel disruption tomorrow and into Thursday morning.

The Met Office has warned of delays on roads that could strand vehicles and passengers, as well as longer journey times on bus and train services.

The weather warning, which in place for all of Sussex, now lasts from midnight tomorrow until 9am on Thursday.

A spokesman for the Met Office said that the warning has also been extended to cover a larger part of southern England.

He said: "The warning has also been extended into Thursday, primarily to include residual ice impacts that may persist into the morning travel period."

Dale Hipkiss, national network manager at National Highways, urged people to plan their journeys ahead of time, listen to weather forecasts, and adjust driving behaviour according to the conditions on the roads.

He said: "Freezing conditions bring so many hazards such as snow and ice, so take every possible step to understand your journey in advance and allow lots of extra time when travelling to prepare for the unexpected.

"Keeping a kit of essential items like a torch and warm clothes in your vehicle can be vital in case you and your passengers become stranded."

results.title: Met Office updates snow warning to include most of Wales
results.body:
A Met Office warning for snow in Wales has been updated to include most of the country on Thursday. The forecasting service issued a new warning on Tuesday morning as some forecasters warn of "disruptive" snow by the end of the week.

There are now two different yellow warnings for Wales on Thursday that cover most of the country. The new warning for south Wales warns that ice could cause issues during the morning commute on Thursday.

A yellow warning that starts at midnight on Wednesday and now runs until 9am on Thursday says: "An area of rain, sleet and snow is expected to develop over southwest England during Tuesday evening and move east during early Wednesday before clearing mid-morning. Whilst drier conditions may develop for a time through the middle of the day, a further spell of sleet and snow is likely to develop during the afternoon and move east into the evening. There remains significant uncertainty in how far north snow develops as well as whether accumulations are focused mainly over higher ground."

Read more: Met Office forecast as weather warnings for snow and ice descend on Wales

The warning continues: "At this stage, the focus for the higher snow accumulations is across England south of the M4 during later Wednesday where there is a chance that some places could see 5-10 cm falling in a few hours. Earlier in the day and across the wider warning area, accumulations are expected to be lower, typically 1-3 cm. As snow clears on Wednesday night, clearing skies will result in ice developing on untreated surfaces with impacts lingering into Thursday morning."

There are also warnings for snow in north Wales on Thursday and Friday, from 3am on Thursday until 6pm on Friday.

The yellow warning says: "Snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday and Friday as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK. Parts of Northern Ireland, north Wales and northern England are currently expected to see the worst of the conditions on Thursday, with parts of Scotland and northern England then seeing the heaviest snow on Friday.

"Event totals could bring 5 to 10 cm of snow to many locations, even at low elevations, with potentially 15 to 20 cm accumulating across the northern portion of the warning area. Higher elevations of the North Pennines, Southern Uplands, higher parts of the Central Belt and the southern Highlands may see as much as 30 to 40 cm of snow in places. In addition, there is potential for strong winds, which may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow."

BBC Wales forecaster Rhian Haf warned of "disruptive snow" in some parts of Wales on Thursday into Friday. Read more about that here.

Read next:

Tributes paid as loved ones name victims of A48 crash that killed three WRU appoint familiar face in huge job to take charge of coaching in Wales ntruders walk into house and attack man with baseball bat Zachary Levi reveals Welsh roots as he says he loves Wales on The One Show

results.title: Maps show which areas of the UK can expect to be hit with snow this week
results.body:
Parts of the country are already covered in snow - and it is expected to keep falling throughout the week.

They are all under a yellow weather warning for snow and ice today with London, Oxford, Birmingham and Northern Ireland predicted to start clearing up overnight.

But the snow is set to move further south tomorrow, hitting Plymouth and Exeter while remaining in Newcastle and Scotland.

The weather warning is scheduled to be lifted from southern England, Wales and parts of northern Scotland on Thursday, but it will move to cover almost the entirety of the north in England.

This includes Stoke-on-Trent, Liverpool, Manchester, Nottingham and Sheffield. The whole of Northern Ireland is at risk of seeing snow again on this day too.

Things look the same for Friday, with rain and snow moving north this weekend.

The Met Office said the cold snap may last two weeks and temperatures in parts of the UK will not reach double digits until Thursday.

The mercury could drop to -15°C in some areas of the Scottish Highlands - where up to 16 inches of snow could accumulate.

Met Office chief meteorologist Dan Suri warned about the weather causing travel disruption with some rural communities in the north at risk of being completely cut off.

He explained that the UK is facing an Arctic maritime air mass - a low-pressure system - coming in from the North.

The lowest temperature recorded in the UK so far this year is -10.4°C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit near Inverness in the Highlands in the early hours of January 19.

Mr Suri said snow is not the only danger this week, stressing that ice poses many risks too.

He said: 'Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday.'

The UK Health Security Agency issued a cold weather warning last weekend and placed north-west England and Yorkshire under a level 3 alert.

This means there is a 90% chance of severely cold weather, icy conditions or heavy snow, which could increase the health risk to vulnerable people. The rest of the UK has been placed under level 2.

results.title: Snow update as Met Office issues new warning of ice for Dorset
results.body:
A yellow weather warning will now be in force for Bournemouth, Christchurch, Poole and the rest of the county from midnight on Wednesday until 9am on Thursday, March 9.

The Met Office said there is a chance some places south of the M4 could see snow accumulations of 5 to 10cm in a few hours on Wednesday evening.

Earlier in the day, between 1cm and 3cm of snow could be seen more widely.

The Met Office said as snow clears on Wednesday night, clearing skies will result in ice developing on untreated surfaces with impacts lingering into Thursday morning.

In terms of what to expect, the Met Office says:

results.title: Now snow warning extended to cover whole of Cornwall starting tonight
results.body:
The Met Office has extended its yellow warning for snow to cover the whole of Cornwall with it expected to develop over Tuesday evening

An area of rain, sleet and snow is expected to develop over southwest England during Tuesday evening and move east during early Wednesday before clearing mid-morning.

Whilst drier conditions may develop for a time through the middle of the day, a further spell of sleet and snow is likely to develop during the afternoon and move east into the evening.

The warning extends right across the south (Image: Met Office)

There remains significant uncertainty in how far north snow develops as well as whether accumulations are focused mainly over higher ground.

At this stage, the focus for the higher snow accumulations is across England south of the M4 during later Wednesday where there is a chance that some places could see 5-10 cm falling in a few hours.

Earlier in the day and across the wider warning area, accumulations are expected to be lower, typically 1-3 cm. As snow clears on Wednesday night, clearing skies will result in ice developing on untreated surfaces with impacts lingering into Thursday morning.

Met Office Chief Meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north.

"Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off. Snow showers will continue through today and Tuesday here, and Northern Ireland will also be subject to some snow showers, especially over high ground.

"Ice will provide an additional hazard for many with overnight low temperatures well below 0°C for many. Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday."

results.title: Scotland snow forecast names full list of areas caught in four-day warning
results.body:
The Met Office has named the areas that could get the most snow over the next four days, as many parts of Scotland have been placed under a yellow weather warning.

The northeast has already seen wintery conditions arrive as Aberdeen has woken up to a thick blanket of the white stuff - and there could be more to come.

The Met Office has warned that even lower areas in the northeast could expect some 5cm of snow early this week, while higher areas could see more than 20cm. But by Thursday, most of Scotland will be enveloped in a snow warning as the Arctic blast continues.

Elsewhere in the UK, the Met Office have said that snowy conditions this week could reach as far south as northern England and Northern Ireland.

Met Office Chief Meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north.

"Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off."

The weather expert adds that Ice could provide an "additional hazard" for many with overnight temperatures dropping well below 0C for many.

As for the latter parts of the week, Met Office Deputy Chief Meteorologist Steven Keates said the areas that would be most impacted aren't yet known, and that more warnings are likely to arrive.

He said: "Through Thursday and Friday the snow risk spreads to central and northern areas of the UK, though it's not possible to pick out precise locations regarding who will see the heaviest snowfall.

"With a developing situation, it's important to stay up to date with the latest forecast and further warnings are very likely."

Snow weather warning areas: Tuesday and Wednesday

Central, Tayside & Fife

Angus Dundee Fife Perth and Kinross

Grampian

Aberdeen Aberdeenshire Moray

James Coles of Scottish Mountain Rescue and Team Leader at Moffat Mountain Rescue commented: "The UK is entering a period of increasingly challenging weather conditions with snow, ice and gusty winds all featuring prominently in the forecast for the coming week.

"Upland areas, especially in the mountains, can see conditions change very rapidly and they may be markedly different from surrounding lowland areas."

Don't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - sign up to our daily newsletter here .

results.title: Scotland snow map as bone-chilling -15C Arctic air to bring coldest night
results.body:
Scotland woke up to snow today as the Met Office has warned tonight may be the coldest of the year.

With yellow weather warnings in place until Friday, March 10, there is a chance temperatures may plummet to -15C on Tuesday night in some Scottish glens, especially where there is fresh snowfall.

New weather maps by the Met Office show a bout of bone-chilling Arctic air travelling southwards across Scotland, bringing cold temperatures and snowfall on Tuesday.

Weather warnings for snow and ice are in place across all four nations of the UK and more are expected to be issued as Arctic air sweeps across the country. Snow drifts could occur on Friday, the Met Office said.

The lowest temperature recorded in the UK so far this year is minus 10.4C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit near Inverness in the Highlands in the early hours of January 19. Temperatures are set to drop almost six degrees below their coldest last March, when they reached minus 9.1C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire.

Meteorologist Alex Deacon said: "There's low pressure heading down through the north sea and that has allowed the doors to open to Arctic air. We also have this weather front trickling southwards and that is going to produce a mixture of rain, sleet and snow across parts of the south on Tuesday morning and potentially, things could be pretty icy as well."

Snow began falling in Northern Scotland on Monday afternoon. A yellow weather alert in place until Wednesday at 10am is set to impact north and eastern regions most, with up to 5cm of snowfall expected on lower ground, while higher areas will see up to 10cm.

However a second warning in place from 3am on Thursday to 6pm on Friday could see more than 20cm of snowfall in parts of the country. Scotland is expected to see the heaviest fall on Friday as elevated areas could get a hefty 40cm.

The Met Office warned travel disruption is likely and journey times by car, train and bus may take longer than usual. Scots in certain areas woke up to heavy snow on Tuesday morning and are facing "significant disruptions" due to closed roads.

People are at risk of slipping and falling on icy patches of untreated roads, pavements and paths while some rural communities could become cut off from the power grid.

Dale Hipkiss, National Network Manager at National Highways, said people should keep warm clothes and a torch in their car in case they get stuck in icy conditions.

He said: "Freezing conditions bring so many hazards such as snow and ice. Take every possible step to understand your journey in advance and allow lots of extra time when travelling to prepare for the unexpected."

On March 14 1958 the mercury dropped to a record low for the month of minus 22.8C at Logie Coldstone, Aberdeenshire.

The area of low pressure is to clear up by Wednesday, but will be replaced with a similar front moving from the west. By Thursday, it will travel over Scotland, brining moisture to colder air, resulting in "heavy snowfall", lasting until Friday.

Don't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily newsletter here .

READ NEXT: Flight attendant explains benefit of skipping in-flight meals on long haul trips Experts reveal 'best' own-brand tomato soup - and it costs three times less than Heinz M&S brings back £10 steak dinner bargain - but there's a catch

results.title: Weather warning for snow and ice for Burton and South Derbyshire
results.body:
A weather warning has been put in place for Burton and South Derbyshire as temperatures have dropped. The Met Office has put out a yellow warning for snow and ice today, Tuesday, March 7.

The weather warning is in place for this morning but it does appear to be a mostly dry and bright day, but cold as temperatures are only set to hit 4C at the highest. The warning states that ice and some snow could lead to difficult travel conditions in places.

The Met Office also has a second warning in place for snow on Thursday, March 9, with light snow showers forecast for throughout the morning. However, that is looking like it will turn to rain in the afternoon and the area does appear to be on the edge of the weather warning as the north of the country looks like it is to be hit a lot harder.

The warning states that snow has the potential to cause significant disruption and there is a small chance of delays to bus, rail and air travel. It states that some communities could be cut off as a result but as only light snow is forecast it appears that Burton and South Derbyshire will be less impacted than other areas.

Tomorrow, Wednesday, March 8, will be a less eventful day with the Met Office predicting it will be a cloudy start to the day which will change to sunny intervals by late morning. Temperatures will hit highs of 5C.

NEWSLETTER: Sign up for free email alerts to StaffordshireLive straight to your inbox here

Plan to make Burton a tourist hotspot with its river the 'blue jewel'

'Amazing' £2k Titanic antique found hidden in Burton kitchen by Bargain Hunt's Charles Hanson

Motorist calls for Romans to finish work in Shobnall Road in Burton after long delay

New shops and leisure unit set to open at growing Burton retail park

Terrifying 'ghost train' reported in Swadlincote - by two police officers

results.title: Cotswolds to wake up to snow, says Met Office
results.body:
The Met Office has said people could be waking up to snow on Wednesday. And people in the Cotswolds could see a 'fair amount' of the white stuff tomorrow.

People living in the north of England woke up to snow on Tuesday and it could be those further south who open their curtains to see snowfall on Wednesday. More than 10cm of snow fell in parts of northern Scotland on Monday and 20cm of snow could fall later in the week as a cold snap brings snow, ice, wind and rain.

A severe weather warning for snow and ice will be in place for parts of Gloucestershire throughout Wednesday and has been extended into 9am on Thursday. The Met Office and BBC Weather have forecast heavy snow for the Forest of Dean either on Wednesday evening or the early hours of Thursday.

READ MORE: Live snow updates in Gloucestershire with major UK weather change underway

People in southern England and South Wales can expect to wake up to snow on Wednesday but it is unclear whether it will settle, the Met Office has said. Snow is more likely to settle when it moves across much of northern England, Northern Ireland and much of Scotland on Thursday.

Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said people should "expect to wake up to snow" on Wednesday if they live in the South. He said: "I think over higher grounds such as Exmoor, the Chilterns and the Cotswolds there will be a fair amount of snow.

"Elsewhere it is going to be quite difficult, especially after today's wet weather , to say how much snow will settle."

Tuesday could be the coldest night of the year so far with the mercury plunging to minus 15C in some isolated Scottish glens. South-west England, the south coast and South Wales will be covered by a yellow warning for snow all day on Wednesday and a few centimetres of it could fall in those areas.

Mr Burkill warned people to travel in snowy conditions only if essential and to bring a blanket in case they get stuck overnight. He said: "Through the worst of the weather, keep up to date with warnings, be prepared your journey may take longer than normal and you may end up stranded in your car.

"If there is significant snow take water and maybe a blanket just in case, that's if you absolutely need to travel. Treat the weather sensibly and be aware it could be dangerous."

The UK Health Security Agency has issued a level-three cold weather alert for the whole of England which is likely to be reviewed in the coming days. The agency's head of extreme events and health protection Dr Agostinho Sousa said people should check on vulnerable relatives and told pensioners and anyone with an underlying health condition to heat their home to at least 18C.

READ NEXT

Met Office gives exact time heavy snow could hit Gloucestershire in UK winter blast Live snow updates in Gloucestershire with major UK weather change underway Gas pipeline through Cotswolds given go-ahead Schools close due to heating problems as temperatures fall in Gloucestershire New high-rise planned for Cheltenham near GCHQ

results.title: When snow will hit as Met Office issues weather warning amid freezing conditions
results.body:
Greater Manchester has been warned to expect heavy snow across the region this week as temperatures reach near-freezing levels.

In the latter half of the week, the Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for 'heavy snow' across Greater Manchester. Meteorologists have warned that the heavy snow could cause significant disruption to travel and the operation of public services.

This could result in delayed or cancelled buses and trains while some roads may be blocked by deep snow. The current weather warning also covers large parts of the North West including Liverpool, Sheffield, Leeds, and Bradford.

Read more: Mum of young woman involved in Wales crash hits out at police after three found dead

The yellow warning will be in effect from 3am on Thursday, March 9 to 6pm on Friday, March 10, with the majority of Northern England seeing snow on Thursday morning and evening.

To help keep you prepared for the upcoming extreme weather, here's a breakdown of the forecasted weather on Thursday and Friday...

Weather forecast for Greater Manchester on Thursday

Temperatures will be extremely cold on Thursday as temperatures reach as low as 1C, however, the 'feels like' temperatures will be far colder at -3C in the morning. This will be accompanied by moderately high winds reaching as high as 28mph.

According to early forecasts, light snow is predicted to begin falling from 9am in the morning and will slowly become more severe with heavy snow predicted at 12pm. By the evening, light showers are expected to fall with temperatures slowly increasing into Friday morning.

The Met Office said: "A risk of disruption on Thursday as a band of rain and snow, accompanied by strong winds moves northwards. Sleet and snow clears Friday and turning less cold by Saturday."

Weather forecast for Greater Manchester on Friday

By Friday morning, temperatures will have increased slightly, peaking at 5C with a 'feels like' temperature reaching as low as 0C. For now, it is not expected snow will fall across Manchester, however, with a chance of some snow in the afternoon for Rochdale and Oldham. Much of the region will likely see overcast skies and light rain through the day, though.

Wind speeds will also be relatively mild compared to Thursday, reaching a peak of 23 mph before settling to 17mph in the evening.

Angry residents say they keep finding rough sleepers in their Northern Quarter apartment block - due to its 'reputation' Iconic tower that looms over Manchester city centre set for a makeover 'to reduce risk of Covid' The idea that could help solve Greater Manchester area's 40,000-to-one problem Grandad's own lawyer slams him as 'strikingly unsuccessful' criminal after smashing car into pregnant mum's house Met Office weather map shows snow sweeping across region later this week

results.title: Pictures as UK wakes up to blanket of snow in first day of icy weather
results.body:
People in England and Scotland have woken up to snow as a cold snap begins to hit the UK. More than 10cm of snow fell in parts of northern Scotland on Monday and 20cm of snow could fall later in the week as a cold snap brings snow, ice, wind and rain.

Temperatures dipped to minus 7.6C at Altnaharra in the Scottish Highlands on Monday night and the small hamlet was covered in 12cm of snow, more than anywhere else in the UK. Snow has also settled across Northumberland and North Yorkshire with some spots experiencing 2-3cm of cover.

Tuesday could be the coldest night of the year so far with the mercury plunging to minus 15C in some isolated Scottish glens. People in southern England and South Wales can expect to wake up to snow on Wednesday but it is unclear whether it will settle, the Met Office has said.

Snow is more likely to settle when it moves across much of northern England, Northern Ireland and much of Scotland on Thursday. Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said people should "expect to wake up to snow" on Wednesday if they live in the South.

He said: "I think over higher grounds such as Exmoor, the Chilterns and the Cotswolds there will be a fair amount of snow. Elsewhere it is going to be quite difficult, especially after today's wet weather, to say how much snow will settle."

He added snow which is expected to fall in the north of England, southern Scotland and Northern Ireland on Thursday and Friday is likely to be "much more impactful".

A yellow weather warning for snow and ice is in place in much of northern and eastern Scotland and north-east England until 10am on Wednesday. South-west England, the south coast and South Wales will be covered by a yellow warning for snow all day on Wednesday and a few centimetres of it could fall in those areas.

Mr Burkill said his area could be extended to include London. Northern England, North Wales, most of Scotland and Northern Ireland will be covered by a yellow warning for snow between 3am on Thursday and 6pm on Friday.

results.title: Weather warning for Bradford as district braced for heavy snow this week
results.body:
BRADFORD is included in a yellow warning with heavy snow set for the district later this week.

The district is forecast to have spells of snow of Thursday, according to the Met Office.

Heavy snow showers will start in Bradford at noon on Thursday and continue throughout the rest of the day, with temperatures only reaching a high of 1C.

The snow will turn to sleet showers this Friday until 3pm, when dry and cloudy conditions will take over as temperatures will reach a high of 4C.

Bradford is part of a wider yellow warning for heavy snow for large parts of the UK for this Thursday.

The yellow warning runs from 3am on Thursday, March 9 to 6pm on Friday, March 10. It covers Scotland, Northern Ireland, northern England, parts of the Midlands and North Wales.

The Met Office warning says heavy snow has the potential to cause significant disruption on Thursday and Friday.

Today (Tuesday) will be a dry and sunny day with temperatures reaching a high of 4C, which will plunge to -3 overnight tonight.

Tomorrow (Wednesday) will also be a dry and sunny day but colder, as mercury will only reach 4C and -1C overnight.

results.title: UK braces for coldest night of the year with temperatures set to plummet to -15°C
results.body:
Tuesday night could be the coldest so far this year with temperatures expected to drop as low as -15°C in the UK, the Met Office has warned.

This would break the current record of -10.4°C recorded in the Scottish Highlands earlier this year.

The coldest areas on Tuesday are likely to be in sheltered Scottish glens, particularly where there is fresh snow cover.

The Met Office and the UK's Health Security Agency issued warnings for snow and ice in large parts of the country this week.

The arctic air sweeping across the UK is due to a "highly amplified" jet stream, mixed with an area of lower pressure over the mid-North Atlantic, which is pushing air up into northern areas and back down towards the UK.

Yellow warnings have been issued across the UK, with London, the Thames Valley, East Anglia, parts of the Midlands, and South Wales all affected from 9pm on Monday night until 10am on Tuesday. Northern Ireland will also be affected during this time.

Another yellow warning is in place for much of Northern and Eastern Scotland and north-east England until 10am on Wednesday. South-west England and South Wales will be covered by a yellow warning for snow all day on Wednesday, with a few centimetres of snow expected to fall in those areas.

The Met Office warnings for ice and some snow could lead to difficult travel conditions in some places. A band of rain is expected to move southward through the course of Monday evening and early Tuesday, which could turn into snow on hills and possibly lower levels in some areas.

While many areas will see little to no accumulation of snow, 1 to 2cm could settle in some spots, particularly over high ground and southern parts of the warning area.

The rain and snow are expected to turn light and patchy as it slowly clears southern England on Tuesday. However, as skies clear overnight, ice is also likely to form readily on untreated surfaces.

The Met Office urged people in affected areas to stay alert to changing weather and heed the advice of local authorities. It's also advisable to take necessary precautions, such as dressing warmly and driving safely on icy roads.

The Met Office has issued some guidance for driving in the heavy snow and icy conditions.

results.title: National Grid issues energy warning as snow and -10C freeze hits UK
results.body:
National Grid has issued an energy warning as cold weather hits - with hours of snow forecast and a minus TEN cold snap predicted by the Met Office for parts of the UK. National Grid is warming its emergency coal plants in case they're needed today.

The National Grid Electricity System Operators said: "This notification is not confirmation that the unit will be used on Tuesday, but that it will be available to the ESO, if required. The ESO as a prudent system operator has developed these tools for additional contingency to operate the network as normal.

"This does not mean electricity supplies are at risk." Tuesday night could be the coldest of the year so far, the Met Office has announced, as it issued weather warnings for snow and ice across the UK.

READ MORE Met Office shares exact date -10C snow blast ends and UK finally warms up

The forecasting body said the mercury could drop to minus 15C in some sheltered Scottish glens, especially where there is fresh snow cover. The lowest temperature recorded in the UK so far this year is minus 10.4C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit near Inverness in the Highlands in the early hours of January 19.

Temperatures are set to drop almost six degrees below their coldest last March, when they reached minus 9.1C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire. Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge said temperatures could drop to minus 1C in Manchester and 2C in London on Monday night.

"Temperatures will be much, much colder than we would expect at this time of year," he warned. The pattern will set in for some time. We have got this feed of cold air coming in from a much higher latitude. We expect these conditions to remain in place until at least next weekend and possibly longer because sometimes these conditions can be quite stubborn and not easily subject to change."

The UK Health Security Agency has issued a level-three cold weather alert for the whole of England which is likely to be reviewed in the coming days.

results.title: When, where and how much snow is expected to fall in North Wales
results.body:
North Wales is under a two day weather warning for snow which starting 3am on Thursday this week. The Met Office yellow alert covers the six North Wales counties as temperatures remain cold across the region.

The national weather forecasting agency has warned the wintry conditions could cause travel disruption and interrupt power supplies.

According to Met Office maps, these are the main locations, where and when, snow is forecast to fall on Thursday, with rain predicted to replace the snowfall in many areas later in the day.

Read more: Motorcyclist suffers 'serious injuries' after crash involving three other vehicles

6am

Bala (light snow) Blaenau Ffestiniog (light snow) St Asaph (light snow) Pwllheli (sleet)

9am

Holyhead (light snow) Amlwch (light snow) Colwyn Bay (light snow) St Asaph (light snow) Flint (light snow) Ruthin (light snow) Wrexham (light snow) Blaenau Ffestiniog (sleet) Bala (light snow)

12pm

Wrexham (heavy snow) Flint (light snow) Bala (sleet) Ruthin (sleet)

Here is the Met Office weather forecast for Wales:

Today:

A bright day in the north today with sunny spells and a few snow showers. Cloudier further south with outbreaks of light rain, sleet, and snow, which will slowly clear southwards throughout the day. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 6 °C.

Tonight:

A dry, clear and very frosty night in the north. Further south it will be often cloudy with some outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow affecting the far south. Minimum temperature -6 °C.

How is the weather affecting you? Let us know in the comments section:

Wednesday:

A bright and frosty start in the north, cloudier further south with some rain or snow, especially over higher ground. Feeling cold, with a brisk breeze in the south. Maximum temperature 5 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday:

Bands of rain, sleet and snow, accompanied by strong winds will move in during Thursday, before gradually clearing Friday. Turning less cold by Saturday, with rain arriving later.

Cyclist has died after crash that closed North Wales road for hours

Three killed in horror Welsh crash named by loved ones who pay agonising tributes

What you had to say about councillors in Conwy approving Wales' biggest council tax increase

Moment Jaguar driver accelerated away after crashing into house leaving scene of chaos, caught on camera

Men caught looking after £1 million cannabis factory in building on Bangor High Street

results.title: Snow blankets parts of UK as Britons brace for coldest night of 2023
results.body:
From Tyneside to Buckinghamshire, snow fell across the much of the country on Tuesday as forecasters warned temperatures could plunge to a 2023 record low of -15C in some parts.

The Met Office says the mercury could dip to the lowest of the year so far in some sheltered Scottish glens, especially where there is fresh snow cover.

Warnings for snow and ice are in place across all four nations of the UK and more are expected to be issued as Arctic air sweeps across the country.

Related: UK weather: Tuesday night could be coldest of year so far, Met Office warns

The lowest temperature recorded in the UK so far this year is -10.4C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit near Inverness in the Highlands in the early hours of 19 January.

On Tuesday morning, people were waking up to snow across Scotland, Northumberland, Tyne and Wear, Yorkshire, Bedfordshire and Buckinghamshire.

Temperatures are forecast to drop almost 6C below their coldest last March, when they reached -9.1C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire.

A yellow weather warning for snow and ice will be in place for London, the Thames Valley, East Anglia, parts of the Midlands and south Wales until 10am on Tuesday.

An identical one will be in place in Northern Ireland at the same time. A yellow weather warning for snow and ice is in place in much of Northern and eastern Scotland and north-east England.

The area covered by it is likely to extend as far south as Hull from Tuesday before it lifts at about 10am on Wednesday.

South-west England and south Wales will be covered by a yellow warning for snow all day on Wednesday and a few centimetres of snow could fall in those areas.

North England, north Wales, most of Scotland and Northern Ireland will be covered by a yellow warning for snow between 3am on Thursday and 6pm on Friday.

The Met Office spokesperson Grahame Madge said: "Temperatures will be much, much colder than we would expect at this time of year. The pattern will set in for some time. We have got this feed of cold air coming in from a much higher latitude.

"We expect these conditions to remain in place until at least next weekend and possibly longer, because sometimes these conditions can be quite stubborn and not easily subject to change."

The Met Office said travel disruption was likely and journey times by car, train and bus could take longer than usual.

People are at risk of slipping and falling on icy patches of untreated roads, pavements and paths while some rural communities could become cut off from the power grid.

Dale Hipkiss, the national network manager at National Highways, said people should keep warm clothes and a torch in their car in case they got stuck in icy conditions.

He said: "Freezing conditions bring so many hazards such as snow and ice. Take every possible step to understand your journey in advance and allow lots of extra time when travelling to prepare for the unexpected."

The UK Health Security Agency has issued a level-three cold weather alert for the whole of England, which is likely to be reviewed in the coming days.

The agency's head of extreme events and health protection, Dr Agostinho Moreira de Sousa, said people should check on vulnerable relatives and advised pensioners and anyone with an underlying health condition to heat their home to at least 18C.
