results.title: Weather maps show snow over Plymouth as warning in place
results.body:
Plymouth could be set to see snow as large parts of Devon and Cornwall are forecast to get a sprinkling of the white stuff on a latest weather map. It comes as a yellow weather warning is in place across the city from midnight tonight until 11.59pm on Wednesday.

UK Weather Chase has warned of ice on untreated surfaces and expects to see between 5cm to 10cm of snow across Bodmin Moor, Dartmoor and Exmoor. It also added that 'many parts can expect accumulations of 1cm to 2cm of snow'.

In a post of Facebook, UK Weather Chase said: "Looks like some of us could be waking up Wednesday morning to snow. Those in the South, Southwest and wales looks to be in the potential snow threat following the yellow warning issued by the Met Office.

"Spells of snow reaching parts of southwest England late on Tuesday evening will then spread north during the early hours of Wednesday before clearing away eastwards during Wednesday daytime. Many parts can expect accumulations of 1 to 2cm of snow whilst over higher parts of southwest England, especially Bodmin Moor, Dartmoor and Exmoor, along with the hills and mountains of south Wales 5 to 10cm of snow is likely for some.

"Untreated surfaces are also expected to become icy. We will indeed be observing locally around Dartmoor National Park and will throughout keep everyone posted."

The yellow weather warning affecting part of Plymouth and large parts of Devon and Cornwall is for snow and is active from midnight tonight and 11.59pm on Wednesday. The Met Office says: "A period of snow is likely to cause some travel disruption during Wednesday."

The Met Office says to expect There is a small chance of travel delays on roads with some stranded vehicles and passengers, along with delayed or cancelled rail and air travel There is a slight chance that some rural communities could become cut off There is a small chance that power cuts will occur and other services, such as mobile phone coverage, may be affected A small chance of injuries from slips and falls on icy surfaces There is a slight chance that bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times

Devon and Cornwall is not currently included in any other Met Office warnings throughout the week. The majority of Scotland, parts of northern England, the Midlands, north Wales and Northern Ireland are all covered by a warning for heavy snow on Thursday and Friday.

Met Office chief meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north.

"Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off. Snow showers will continue through today and Tuesday here, and Northern Ireland will also be subject to some snow showers, especially over high ground.

"Ice will provide an additional hazard for many with overnight low temperatures well below 0°C for many. Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday."

Want more of the news you love? Sign up to our bespoke newsletters here.

Read more:

Met Office four-day UK heavy snow warning as weather maps show 'Beast from East' arriving Huge barn fire sees 300 sheep rescued in Kingsbridge Plymouth woman found dead by concerned friends in tragic circumstances Surfer's horrific injury after being attacked by a seal in Cornwall Plymouth greengrocer pays 'full whack' to avoid stock shortages for his loyal customers

results.title: Yellow weather warning for snow in Bolton
results.body:
A yellow warning for snow has been issued for Bolton at the end of this week.

The Met Office have issued the alert for the town on Thursday and Friday.

Heavy snow is predicted to fall from noon onwards.

The Met Office has warned that snowfall has the potential to cause significant disruption in the area, along with most of Northern England, North Wales, Northern Ireland and a majority of Scotland.

Thursday will start cold at 0° at 6am, warming up to 2° by 12pm and staying that way until 9pm where the temperature will rise to 3°.

The Met Office's snow warning (Image: Met Office)

There is an 80 per cent chance of snow at 12 noon according to the Met Office, it is expected to turn to sleet by 3pm.

A 60 per cent chance of light rain is then expected until 6am on Friday, dropping to 50 per cent until 3pm.

The Met Office give this guidance for heavy snow:

There is a small chance that long delays and cancellations on bus, rail and air travel could occur

There is a slight chance that roads may become blocked by deep snow, with many stranded vehicles and passengers

There is a small chance that communities could be cut off for several days

There is a small chance that long interruptions to power supplies and other services, such as gas, water, telephone and mobile phone coverage, may occur

This comes as the Met Office report that tonight (Tuesday) could be the coldest night of the year so far in the country.

Snow and ice warnings have also been issued across the UK for the whole of this week.

Met Office Chief Meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north.

"Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off.

"Snow showers will continue through today and Tuesday here, and Northern Ireland will also be subject to some snow showers, especially over high ground.

"Ice will provide an additional hazard for many with overnight low temperatures well below 0°C for many. Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday."

results.title: Devon braced for snow and heavy rain in wintry forecast
results.body:
Devon is set for flurries of snow and heavy rain tomorrow (March 8). The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for snow which covers the county.

The warning is in place from midnight tonight and is set to remain in place until 11.59pm tomorrow. The Exeter-based forecaster says: "A period of snow is likely to cause some travel disruption during Wednesday."

According to the latest forecast, Dartmoor is set to see flurries of the white stuff as early as 1am tomorrow. It will gradually get heavier throughout the morning before turning into heavy rain by midday.

READ MORE: Huge barn fire sees 300 sheep rescued in Kingsbridge

Elsewhere in the county, Crediton should expect light snow throughout tonight before ending by around 10am tomorrow. However, Exeter, Torbay and North Devon are set to see more rain than snow during the yellow warning.

The radar suggests that light rain will hit Exeter by 10am tomorrow, before turning heavier through the afternoon. It adds that "feels like" temperatures will hover between 0C and -1C throughout the day.

Meanwhile, heavy rain is set to batter Torbay for much of the 24-hour warning. Similarly, residents in North Devon should expect downpours from around 1am until the end of the day.

Here is what the Met Office says to expect during the weather warning:

There is a small chance of travel delays on roads with some stranded vehicles and passengers, along with delayed or cancelled rail and air travel. There is a slight chance that some rural communities could become cut off. There is a small chance that power cuts will occur and other services, such as mobile phone coverage, may be affected. A small chance of injuries from slips and falls on icy surfaces. There is a slight chance that bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times. Met Office five-day forecast for the South West

Today: Cloudy on Tuesday with outbreaks of rain and sleet, perhaps some snow, especially over hills. This gradually moves its way southwards, turning patchier and lighter though staying rather cloudy. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 7C.

Tonight: Outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow likely to spread northeastwards overnight, with some lying snow likely by dawn, especially over higher ground. Cold with the risk of icy patches. Minimum temperature -1C.

Wednesday: Mostly cloudy with further outbreaks of mainly light rain, sleet, or snow during the morning. Briefly turning drier before rain or snow returns later with strengthening winds. Maximum temperature 6C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday: Turning milder later in the week though staying unsettled with further rain at times and often rather windy, with some strong winds on Friday. A slight improvement on Saturday.

Read next:

Family nearly hit by boy racers on troubled road

Derelict Johnsons Cleaners site in Exeter to be turned into student flats

Further problems plague controversial Exeter high-rise home development

Town in shock after Ukrainian schoolgirl's unexplained death

Met Office maps show where and when it will snow in Devon

results.title: Four weather warnings in four days as 'heavy snow' expected
results.body:
Weather warnings have been issued by the Met Office for Lincolnshire over the next four days with 'heavy snow' expected later this week. Forecast snowfall will mostly affect northern Lincolnshire and near the coast on Tuesday, March 7 and Wednesday, March 8, before it heads further south on Thursday and Friday.

The Met Office has sent out a yellow-grade snow and ice warning for the north of England, including the region around Hull, Grimsby, Waltham and Immingham. According to the forecaster, 'frequent snow showers' will potentially cause disruption for motorists and rural residents.

Met Office guidance says that, under a yellow ice and snow warning, there is a "small chance" of travel delays - including the potential cancellation of rail and air services - and of people slipping and injuring themselves. Power cuts could also occur and other services, such as mobile phone coverage, could be affected.

Read more: 34-hour snow warning for Lincolnshire as plunging temperatures spark health alert

Some rural communities could even be "cut off". The cold weather is expected to then creep further south into Lincolnshire on Thursday.

A separate yellow-grade snow warning has been issued from 3am on Thursday, March 9 until 6pm on Friday,March 10 with Lincoln set to be in the very heart of it. According to projections, Spilsby will be the cut-off for the east of the county.

While towns like Coningsby will be affected, the bad weather will not go further south than Sleaford. The "heavy snow" forecast has the potential to cause "significant disruptions" across the two days.

The Met Office has said there is a "slight" chance that roads may become blocked by deep snow, stranding drivers, and that communities could again be "cut off" for several days. On top of the small chance that power supplies and other services, such as gas, water and phone coverage, could be interrupted for a long time, there is also the same 'small chance' that bus, rail and air services could suffer delays or cancellations.

Drivers wishing to travel in snowy and icy conditions should follow the Met Office's guidance on how to stay safe.

Poll: Are you planning an event for King Charles III's coronation?

Read next:

Exercise Cobra Warrior: Weather forecast for week ahead

Life in the village next to 'the worst road in Lincolnshire'

The Roman roads in Lincolnshire you might drive on every day

Exercise Cobra Warrior: Special exclusive spectator event sells out in under an hour

Family of man killed on first day of lockdown left 'alone and lost' after fatal crash

results.title: Yellow alert: Up to 8 cm of snow expected in northern Luxembourg on Wednesday
results.body:
Meteolux has issued a yellow alert for Wednesday due to a risk of snow across Luxembourg.

Winter is far from over! While the week already kicked off with a clear drop in temperatures and some snow, Meteolux has just issued a yellow snow alert for Wednesday.

The alert will be in effect for the whole country until 8am, with "4 to 8 cm of snow potentially accumulating in the north and 1 to 2 cm in the south."

Temperatures are expected to start at 0°C on Wednesday before rising to 9°C in the afternoon. The following days, a renewed increase in temperatures should keep the risk of more snow at bay, but the sky is still expected to remain rainy and grey until Sunday.

results.title: Met Office issues yellow warning for snow in Notts
results.body:
A yellow weather warning has been issued for snow in Nottingham with the Met Office warning of potentially 'significant disruption'. The alert is issued from 3am on Thursday March 9 and continues until 6pm on Friday March 10.

The forecaster warns that the alert means that travellers could face 'long delays and cancellations on bus, rail and air travel'. It adds: "There is a slight chance that roads may become blocked by deep snow, with many stranded vehicles and passengers. There is a small chance that communities could be cut off for several days.

"There is also small chance that long interruptions to power supplies and other services, such as gas, water, telephone and mobile phone coverage, may occur." According to the map showing the alert, the warning stretches down from Scotland to just south of Nottingham.

Read more: Hour by hour Nottinghamshire weather forecast as Met Office warning issued for snow and ice

The Met Office forecast for this period suggests that the temperature will be as low as 0C but will feel like -3C due to wind chill. The BBC says that sleet and wintry showers are likely to reach Nottingham around 9am on Thursday - and last for a number of hours.

The whole day could see lots of rain - and if the temperature is cold enough it could turn to snow and sleet. The Met Office forecast for Thursday in Nottingham says: "Staying cold with frosts overnight. Risk of disruptive snow and strong winds to occur on Thursday and Friday. Saturday looking drier and brighter."

The longer range predictions from Saturday March 11 - Monday March 20 adds: "Confidence in the details are low throughout this period. On Saturday, cold conditions are expected across the north, accompanied by showers, some of these possibly wintry, although some sunny spells are possible."

It comes as a nationwide level three cold weather alert has been put in place by the Met Office and the UK Health Security Agency. The alert warns the weather will turn extremely cold from 1am Monday (March 6) to midnight on Wednesday (March 8).

Commenting on the alert, Dr Agostinho Sousa, head of extreme events and health protection at UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA), said: "During periods like this, it is important to check in on family, friends and relatives who may be more vulnerable to the cold weather, as it can have a serious impact on health.

"If you have a pre-existing medical condition or are over the age of 65, it is important to try and heat your home to at least 18C if you can."

Read next:

New traders in as unique shop bounces back from liquidation Part of the city centre where a number of shops have closed Gym demolition in restoration of railway station with rich history Life in the Nottinghamshire village that is 'so unique' it attracts shoppers from across county 'Mid-range hotel' among calls for city's former Debenhams building

results.title: Snow arrives in Northern Ireland with cold snap set to continue
results.body:
A weather warning for snow and ice remains in place across Northern Ireland.

Temperatures plummeted overnight as cold northerly air continued to sink south over the UK resulting in a flurry of snow showers.

Clear spells overnight also resulted in widespread frost with daytime temperatures expected to remain low for the rest of the week.

Residents across NI have been sharing images on social media.

A yellow weather warning expires at 10am on Tuesday.

However a second warning has been issued and will come into force at 3pm on Thursday until 6pm on Friday when up to 10cm of snow could fall on lower ground.

Hilly areas could see as much as 20cm fall.

Met Office forecaster Dan Stroud said the mercury will struggle to climb above 4C during the day with cold conditions expected to last throughout the week.

"It will become increasingly unsettled as the week goes on with potential for significant snowfall across Northern Ireland on Thursday into Friday," he added.

"There is a lot of uncertainty at this point though, but 5-10cm is possible on lower ground with 15-20cm on higher ground."

The director of engineering at the Department for Infrastructure has warned that it does not have the capacity to carry out adequate gritting services on Thursday and Friday.

David Porter blamed the lack of resources on ongoing strike action.

"So far it's been as expected, but we are very concerned by what is being forecast later this week," he told BBC Radio Ulster.

"Disruptive snow and continuous snow will give us very significant issues because of the reduced capacity in our gritting service, winter fleet, because of the ongoing industrial action by some of the industrial unions."

Mr Parker confirmed the normal procedure of "constant gritting" during heavy snowfall will not be possible as he urged members of the public to carefully consider travel plans and take extra care on the roads.

results.title: Snowfall in parts of Suffolk this morning
results.body:
Parts of Suffolk have woken up to snowfall this morning (Image: Mollett's Farm)

The snow showers come amid a Met Office amber cold weather alert which remains in place until Thursday.

The Met Office issued a yellow weather warning for snow and ice for the region as temperatures are expected to drop this week.

The Met Office and UK Health Security Agency has also issued a severe cold weather warning for the county between Monday and Thursday.

The snow comes after weather forecasters said Arctic air was going to sweep across the county this week bringing with it a risk of snowfall.

A light dusting of snow was reported in Ipswich in the early hours, while snow started to settle in parts of the east of the county.

results.title: Heavy snowfall leaves commuters facing road chaos while schools closed
results.body:
Scotland to be hit by snow and ice as weather and travel warning issued

Commuters and schoolchildren in northern Scotland faced major disruption on Tuesday morning as the region was hit by a blanket of snow.

Roads have been shut and schools either closed for the day or delayed, as wintry weather has taken hold amid yellow weather warnings.

Traffic Scotland confirmed a number of roads in the region have been closed due to snow cover, including the A93 Braemar to Spittal of Glenshee, A939 Cockbridge to Tomintoul and B974 Banchory to Fettercairn.

It also advised that the A90 from Milltimber to Goval had been closed in both directions, with conditions described as "hazardous".

Schoolchildren in Aberdeenshire were given respite with delayed starts and closures announced early on by the council.

All north east Scotland college campuses were closed, with multiple reports of lorries, cars and buses stuck on snow-covered roads.

Orkney Islands Council announced in a social media post that transport operator JD Peace was advised not to transport pupils to school, and Stagecoach said they will only service A roads throughout Tuesday.

Shetland Islands Council confirmed all schools will be closed across the isles due to "continued cold weather and risk of more snow."

Flights to and from Aberdeen airport were also disrupted, with the runway forced to close amid the adverse weather conditions. Flights began taking off again at 8am.

Weather warnings for Monday and Tuesday were issued last week, covering northern and eastern parts of the country.

Snowfall was forecast across the Western Isles, Highlands, northwest, Orkney, Shetland and down the east coast of Scotland, with STV meteorologist Sean Batty warning temperatures would plunge as low as -15C in areas.

On Monday afternoon, the Met Office additionally confirmed that central, western and southern areas can also expect to see severe snowfall.

The second yellow alert will come into effect at 3am on Thursday and covers all of Scotland, with only the northern Highlands and islands excluded. The warning is in force until 6pm on Friday.

The Met Office said snow could develop quite widely as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK, with parts of Scotland and northern England forecast to see the heaviest snow on Friday.

Up to 10cm is expected widely, even on lower ground - with accumulations as much as 20cm forecast up north.

Higher parts of the Central Belt and the southern Highlands may see as much as 40cm of snow in places.

The Met Office said there was a chance some rural communities could become cut off, with chances of power cuts and adverse affects on other services, such as mobile phone coverage.

Drivers have been warned to take extra care with delays on roads and risk of strandings likely with rail and air travel also facing possible disruption.

results.title: Worst snow since Beast from the East could bring Scotland to standstill with 16inches
results.body:
THE heaviest snowfall since The Beast From the East could bring Scotland to a standstill this week with up to 16 INCHES of the white stuff.

Forecasters are warning that "very challenging conditions" will sweep in on Thursday and Friday, potentially cutting off remote communities for several days and stranding motorists in their vehicles.

Until now, it has been the north of the country which has suffered the worst of the whiteout conditions but now the nation's areas of mass population are in the eye of the snow storm, including Edinburgh and Glasgow.

On top of that, the mercury was expected to plunge to Minus 15C (5F) this morning (Tues) to give us the coldest day of the year so far.

The grim forecast comes almost five years to the day since the Beast from the East paralysed the nation in early March 2018.

Grahame Madge of the Met Office said:"We are about to enter a particularly eventful period of weather.

"Freezing conditions, coupled with heavy snow and drifting all mean that peoples' travel plans will have to be urgently reviewed.

"These risks will only increase as we go through the week.

"I strongly advise people to stay in touch with the forecast and be prepared to cancel travel plans accordingly.

"The warning is suggesting as much as 16 inches of snow, but with winds whipping it into blizzards, accumulations of even greater than that are possible."

On Thursday into Friday, as much as 30-40cm (12-16 inches) could be dumped on higher parts of the central belt, the southern uplands and southern Highlands.

This would affect major road links to the south, including the A1, M74 and the M8 between Glasgow and Edinburgh.

Rail journeys are also likely to be affected and airports may find it impossible to keep runways clear of snow.

The yellow warning states:"Snow could develop quite widely across the warning area on Thursday and Friday as a potentially quite deep area of low pressure moves across the UK.

"Parts of Northern Ireland, north Wales and northern England are currently expected to see the worst of the conditions on Thursday, with parts of Scotland and northern England then seeing the heaviest snow on Friday.

"Event totals could bring 5 to 10 cm (up to 4 inches) of snow to many locations, even at low elevations, with potentially 15 to 20 cm (6 to 8 inches) accumulating across the northern portion of the warning area.

"Higher elevations of the North Pennines, Southern Uplands, higher parts of the Central Belt and the southern Highlands may see as much as 30 to 40 cm (12 to 16 inches) of snow in places.

"In addition, there is potential for strong winds, which may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow."

The warning also predicts possible 'long interruptions' to power supplies, phone and mobile phone connections.

Electricity companies are expected to put repair teams into areas most likely to be affected, schools will almost certainly close and the Scottish Government will activate its resilience team to co-ordinate recovery efforts.

Yesterday, the first effects of the Arctic blast were felt in Aberdeenshire, where some motorists became stuck on the A939 Cockbridge to Tomintoul road.

An HGV also lost traction before making it up one of the highest points on the road.

Snow and ice warnings for the north remain in place right through the week and by the time they end on Friday, they will have been in place for a consecutive 79 hours.

This morning Glasgow could be down to Minus 3C or Minus 4C (24-26F) but by tomorrow morning (Weds) Scotland's biggest city could see Minus 7C (19F).

results.title: Somerset town-by-town forecast as heavy snow looms
results.body:
Somerset is braced for snow and freezing temperatures throughout tonight and tomorrow (March 8). The Met Office has issued two yellow weather warnings covering the county as snow is forecast to impact the region.

The first warning - for snow and ice - came into force at 9pm yesterday (March 6) and is due to deactivate at 10am. The second is for snow from midnight tonight through to 11.59pm tomorrow.

The Exeter-based forecaster says that "a period of snow" is likely to hit the county by early evening tomorrow. It adds that travel disruption is likely.

READ MORE: Cat rescued from Bridgwater house fire that was caused by electric blanket

Locally, Taunton is set for "feels like" temperatures below 0C for most of the day tomorrow. The Met Office predicts sleet to arrive at 5pm before turning into heavy snow at 7pm.

The outlook is similar for Bath, with residents expecting flurries of the white stuff from around 5pm. The heavy snow is forecast to arrive at 7pm, lasting until 10pm.

Meanwhile, Wells should see slightly lighter snow following a period of sleet at 6pm. In Yeovil, heavy snow will arrive at 6pm before easing by 10pm.

According to the radar, Frome is braced for heavy snow fall between 6pm and 9pm. It will then ease into light snow before stopping completely by 11pm.

Finally, Weston-super-Mare looks set to avoid the worst of the snow. However, 'feels like' temperatures will be around -4C by the early evening after a day of heavy rain.

Here is what the Met Office says to expect during the snow warning:

There is a small chance of travel delays on roads with some stranded vehicles and passengers, along with delayed or cancelled rail and air travel. There is a slight chance that some rural communities could become cut off. There is a small chance that power cuts will occur and other services, such as mobile phone coverage, may be affected. A small chance of injuries from slips and falls on icy surfaces. There is a slight chance that bus and train services may be delayed or cancelled, with some road closures and longer journey times. Met Office five-day forecast for the South West

Today: Cloudy on Tuesday with outbreaks of rain and sleet, perhaps some snow, especially over hills. This gradually moves its way southwards, turning patchier and lighter though staying rather cloudy. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 7C.

Tonight: Outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow likely to spread northeastwards overnight, with some lying snow likely by dawn, especially over higher ground. Cold with the risk of icy patches. Minimum temperature -1C.

Wednesday: Mostly cloudy with further outbreaks of mainly light rain, sleet, or snow during the morning. Briefly turning drier before rain or snow returns later with strengthening winds. Maximum temperature 6C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday: Turning milder later in the week though staying unsettled with further rain at times and often rather windy, with some strong winds on Friday. A slight improvement on Saturday.

Read next:

Met Office maps show where and when it will snow in Somerset tomorrow

Man arrested after car reported stolen found in River Stour

Glastonbury Festival 2023 line-up: Lana Del Rey appears to threaten to call off big Worthy Farm show

results.title: Snow set to hit Cov and Warks as several areas in UK wake to snowfall
results.body:
Sleet, snow and rain will hit Coventry and Warwickshire on Thursday according to the Met Office's latest local forecast for our region. It comes as several parts of the UK woke to snow this morning.

A yellow weather warning was in place overnight, but while temperatures have fallen, there has been no sign of snow or ice today (March 7). There is a chance of some wintry showers in parts of the Midlands later today.

However, come Thursday (March 9) the picture could be a lot different. In its weekly forecast for our area, the Met Office has said: "Bands of rain, sleet and snow, accompanied by strong winds will move in during Thursday, before gradually clearing Friday.

READ MORE: Two-year-old allegedly assaulted at Coventry nursery

"Turning less cold by Saturday, with rain arriving later." Tonight will see the temperatures start to plummet with the minimum temperature set to be a bone-chilling -6 °C.

Large parts of Britain have woken to snow today. The Met Office says some areas could soon face "blizzard conditions", the Mirror reports.

Several UK areas are set for more snow and ice. It could last until the end of the week amid possibly the coldest temperatures of the year so far.

Five days of snow and ice warnings have been issued for areas as far afield as Cornwall and Devon, Inverness, Northern Ireland and Wales.

There could be snowfall of between 12 and 15 inches on Thursday and Friday in areas such as the North Pennines, Southern Uplands, higher parts of the Central Belt and the southern Highlands in Scotland. The Met Office says a combination of strong winds and the heavy snow "may lead to blizzard conditions and drifting of lying snow."

The agency predicts: "A major change in the weather is under way for the UK, as cold air moves in from the north, bringing snow, ice and low temperatures for many."

The Met Office Coventry area weather forecast for this week:

Today

Some bright or sunny spells developing but the risk of some further wintry showers throughout the afternoon. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 6 °C.

Tonight

Turning dry with clear skies developing this evening, allowing temperatures to quickly fall away leading to a widespread frost. Cloud however will increase across the south towards dawn. Minimum temperature -6 °C.

Wednesday

A frosty start with some early morning brightness in the north. Otherwise a largely dry, cold and cloudy day with the odd wintry flurry possible in the south. Maximum temperature 5 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday

Bands of rain, sleet and snow, accompanied by strong winds will move in during Thursday, before gradually clearing Friday. Turning less cold by Saturday, with rain arriving later.

For all the latest Coventry news, sign up to our newsletter here.

Coventry businessman blasts 'special treatment' for hotels housing asylum seekers

Depraved former Coventry social worker jailed after child abuse trial

Driver crashes into parked car and concrete bollard in Coventry

Coventry woman in court over murder of five-year-old David-Mario Lazar

Woman furious after buying car so 'filled with damp and mould' that it triggered her asthma

results.title: Snow arrives in Northern Ireland with cold snap set to continue
results.body:
A weather warning for snow and ice remains in place across Northern Ireland.

Temperatures plummeted overnight as cold northerly air continued to sink south over the UK resulting in a flurry of snow showers.

Clear spells overnight also resulted in widespread frost with daytime temperatures expected to remain low for the rest of the week.

Residents across NI have been sharing images on social media.

A yellow weather warning expires at 10am on Tuesday.

However a second warning has been issued and will come into force at 3pm on Thursday until 6pm on Friday when up to 10cm of snow could fall on lower ground.

Hilly areas could see as much as 20cm fall.

Met Office forecaster Dan Stroud said the mercury will struggle to climb above 4C during the day with cold conditions expected to last throughout the week.

"It will become increasingly unsettled as the week goes on with potential for significant snowfall across Northern Ireland on Thursday into Friday," he added.

"There is a lot of uncertainty at this point though, but 5-10cm is possible on lower ground with 15-20cm on higher ground."

results.title: London weather forecast: Coldest night of the year expected as 'highly amplified' jet stream brings Arctic air
results.body:
Tuesday night could be the coldest night of the year for many, with temperatures expected to drop as low as -15C as the UK comes under an arctic blast.

The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has issued a Level 3 Cold Weather Alert for the whole of England and the Met Office has urged people to check on relatives and friends who are vulnerable to icy weather, particularly the elderly.

A level 3 alert means there is a 90 per cent chance of severe cold weather, icy conditions and possibly snow between Monday and Thursday in parts of England.

Arctic air is sweeping across due to a "highly amplified" jet stream which is mixed with lower pressure over the mid-north Atlantic.

The Met Office has predicted London could dip as low as -1C overnight with patchy frost and icy stretches expected, mostly in the north.

The capital is also under a yellow snow and ice warning until 10am on Tuesday after a bitter and rainy Monday night. Some icy patches on roads may cause travel disruption.

Parts of England, including Northumberland and Yorkshire, woke up to fresh snow blanketing fields and houses.

Snow and ice warnings have also been issued for northeastern areas of the UK, including parts of Northern Ireland, England and Wales, until Friday.

Areas affected on Tuesday include Birmingham, Cardiff, Newcastle and most of Scotland.

The chilliest temperatures of the year are set for the Scottish Glens on Tuesday, with a forecast of -15C overnight.

The lowest temperature recorded in the UK so far this year was -10.4C, which was recorded at Drumnadrochit on the shores of Loch Ness in the Highlands in the early hours of January 19.

In excess of 20cm of snow could accumulate over high ground in Scotland and more than 5cm is likely to accumulate even to lower levels in the northeast of the UK, the Met Office said.

Chief Meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north."

Southern England and south Wales are likely to wake up to "couple of centimetres of snow" on Wednesday morning.

In London further snow is expected on Wednesday evening with "some heavier bursts possible at times", with a maximum temperature of 4C.

On Thursday and Friday the snow risk is forecast to spread to central and northern areas of the UK.

Temperatures will creep back up for London later this week, with a high of 9C on Thursday and 10C on Friday.

results.title: UK weather: Home counties awake to snow as -15C coldest night looms
results.body:
Snow has fallen in the home counties as Britain braces for its coldest night of the year.

Arctic air is continuing to move south across the country, with the temperature forecast to drop as low as -15C on Tuesday evening in the Scottish Glens.

This would surpass the current lowest temperature of -10.4C, recorded at Drumnadrochit, a village near Inverness in the Highlands on January 19.

Already, parts of Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire and Suffolk have awoken to snow on Tuesday morning.

The Met Office has issued yellow weather warnings for snow and ice across parts of south-east England, London, south-west England, the Midlands and Wales throughout Wednesday, with the north-east of England, Yorkshire and most of Scotland also covered.

It means disruption to some roads and railways is likely, along with a risk of falls.

Forecasters are expecting two to six centimetres of snow and 10cm on higher ground across the south of England and the Midlands.

However, "heavy snow" is then expected to sweep across England and Scotland north of Birmingham on Thursday and Friday, of 20cm on lower ground and 40cm on higher ground, prompting another Met Office yellow warning which says it "has the potential to cause significant disruption".

The Met Office said "there is a slight chance that roads may become blocked by deep snow" and "a small chance that communities could be cut off for several days", with "long delays" in travel and power disruption also possible.

Dan Suri, the Met Office chief meteorologist, said: "Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off.

"Snow showers will continue through Tuesday here, and Northern Ireland will also be subject to some snow showers, especially over high ground.

"Ice will provide an additional hazard for many with overnight low temperatures well below 0C for many. Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday."

The UK Health Security Agency has extended its "level three cold weather alert" to cover the whole of England until midnight on Thursday, the second-highest alert it can issue.

It means there is a 90 per cent chance of severely cold weather, icy conditions or heavy snow, which could increase the health risk to vulnerable patients.

The coldest temperature recorded last March was -9.1C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire, and the coldest March night ever was in 1958, -22.8C at Logie Coldstone, Aberdeenshire.

results.title: Parts of Norfolk wake up to snow amid Met Office warning
results.body:
Parts of Norfolk have woken up to flurries of snow this morning after a yellow weather warning was issued.

The snow showers come amid a Met Office amber cold weather alert which remains in place until Thursday.

It is the second-highest warning, with the subzero temperatures posing health risks to the vulnerable.

READ MORE: Weather warning issued for snow in Norfolk as temperatures could drop to -8C

East Harling (Image: Supplied)

READ MORE: Warning to dog owners as temperatures set to drop - the breeds most at risk

People in Dereham and East Harling were among those who woke up to a dusting of snow and wintry scenes.

Radio Norfolk reported a "fair dusting" and "very wintry scenes" in parts of the county.

An arctic blast which was due to hit Norfolk last night (March 6) is expected to continue until Wednesday.

The Met Office is forecasting "light snow showers" in Lessingham, Cromer, King's Lynn and Swaffham for short parts of today (March 7).

results.title: Met Office shares exact date -10C snow blast ends and UK finally warms up
results.body:
The exact date snow will end in Birmingham and the Midlands and the weather will take an upturn has been announced by the Met Office. After snow was forecast on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday this week, meteorologists expect the weather to improve through the weekend.

In its forecast, the Met Office promises: "Turning less cold by Saturday, with rain arriving later." Its outlook from March 11 onwards continues: "Confidence in the details are low throughout this period. On Saturday, cold conditions are expected across the north, accompanied by showers, some of these possibly wintry, although some sunny spells are possible. Elsewhere, milder, cloudier conditions are likely, with outbreaks of rain and some stronger winds possible.

"Generally becoming somewhat milder through this period, but colder conditions may linger in the north." Meteorologist Alex Deakin has hinted at snow this week - saying: "There's a low heading down through the North Sea, from the Arctic and that is where our weather is coming from.

READ MORE Met Office announces exact hour snow will hit and every area set for flurries - full list

"This weather front is wet, chiefly rain through Monday and into sleet and snow through the night. It could turn things icy - certainly the showers in Scotland will come in as snow. North East England and south Scotland could see sleet and hail, too." He added: "It could potentially be icy as temperatures drop well below - it could be minus 10 in rural Scotland.

"Further south, temperatures stay a little above freezing." Met Office spokesman Grahame Madge said: "Temperatures will be much, much colder than we would expect at this time of year.

"The pattern will set in for some time. We have got this feed of cold air coming in from a much higher latitude. We expect these conditions to remain in place until at least next weekend and possibly longer because sometimes these conditions can be quite stubborn and not easily subject to change."

results.title: Exact hours snow will hit Birmingham and Midlands announced by Met Office
results.body:
The exact hour snow starts in Birmingham and Midlands ahead of a fresh freezing weather snap this week has been confirmed. The BBC and Met Office are forecasting snow showers and sleet on Tuesday March 7.

Weather warnings for snow and ice are in place across all four nations of the UK and more are expected to be issued as Arctic air sweeps across the country. A yellow weather warning for snow and ice will be in place for London, the Thames Valley, East Anglia, parts of the Midlands and South Wales from 9pm on Monday night until 10am on Tuesday.

According to the Beeb, sleet showers are expected from 10am til midday in Birmingham on Tuesday, before returning at 2pm. In its forecast, it warns: "Today will be cloudy during the morning with a chance of a few light wintry showers in places. Cloud will tend to break up later, with plenty of winter sunshine developing in the late afternoon. Cold.

Met Office announces exact hour snow will hit and every area set for flurries - full list

"Tonight will be cold and largely dry. It will be rather cloudy due to bands of high to middle cloud veiling the skies. Light gentle winds." The Met Office has not forecast snow on Tuesday but is warning snow showers could fall on Thursday March 9, from 6am til 12noon.

The BBC agrees, with light snow showers forecast from 6am til midday on Thursday morning. Neither forecaster has snow in its hour-by-hour forecasts for Wednesday. On Tuesday, its forecast says: "An icy start in places as a band of rain, sleet and snow clears southwards, Some bright or sunny spells developing but the risk of some further wintry showers throughout the afternoon. Feeling cold."

Looking ahead to tonight, the Met Office adds: "Turning dry with clear skies developing this evening, allowing temperatures to quickly fall away leading to a widespread frost. Cloud however will increase across the south towards dawn."

On Wednesday, the Met Office continues: "A frosty start with some early morning brightness in the north. Otherwise a largely dry, cold and cloudy day with the odd wintry flurry possible in the south." Its outlook for Friday to Sunday reads: "Bands of rain, sleet and snow, accompanied by strong winds will move in during Thursday, before gradually clearing Friday. Turning less cold by Saturday, with rain arriving later."

results.title: Snow falls in Worcestershire as Met Office issue weather warning
results.body:
SNOW has been pictured this morning on top of the Malvern Hills after a weather warning was issued across the county.

The yellow weather warning for snow and ice was issued yesterday for Worcestershire by the Met Office.

In the picture, the peaks of the hills can be seen covered with snow in the distance.

The weather warning came into effect at 9pm yesterday (Monday, March 6) and is set to last until 10am today (Tuesday, March 7).

READ MORE: Met Office snow and ice warning

A spokesperson for the Met Office said: "A band of rain will edge southwards through the course of Monday evening and early Tuesday, this rain turning to snow on hills and perhaps to lower levels in places.

"Many areas will see little or no accumulations of snow, but one to two centimetres could settle in some spots, most likely over high ground and southern parts of the warning area.

"The rain and snow is then expected to turn light and patchy as it slowly clears southern England on Tuesday.

"As skies clear overnight, ice is also likely to form readily on untreated surfaces."

The Met Office warns that some snow could lead to difficult travel conditions in places.

Some roads and railways are likely to be affected with longer journey times by road, bus and train services.

People are also at risk of injuries from slips and falls on icy surfaces.

There is likely to be some icy patches on untreated roads, pavements, and cycle paths.

Do you have snow near you? If so, email your pictures to joseph.broady@newsquest.co.uk or message us on Facebook.

results.title: Snow to hit Cheshire as Met Office issue weather warning
results.body:
Snow is set to hit the county later this week.

The Met Office has issued a two-day yellow weather warning which comes into force later in the week.

According to forecasters, snow will arrive early on Thursday morning (March 9). The warning comes into place from 3am and will last until 6pm on Friday.

READ MORE: Decision day for rival Cheshire village crematorium bids

Most of the county will see temperatures of 0C or below freezing on Friday. Macclesfield will be coldest with predicted low of -2C. The likes of Chester and Crewe will see temperatures fall as low as -1C.

The warning states: "Heavy snow has the potential to cause significant disruption on Thursday and Friday."

Met Office Deputy Chief Meteorologist Steven Keates said: "The impactful weather will continue through the second half of the week as mild air meets cold air with further snow, ice, wind and then rain likely later in the week and into the weekend. From Wednesday, the focus of further snow is across parts of southern England and south Wales, with snow likely to lower levels for a time, and many may wake up to a couple of centimetres of snow on Wednesday morning.

"Through Thursday and Friday the snow risk spreads to central and northern areas of the UK, though it's not possible to pick out precise locations regarding who will see the heaviest snowfall. With a developing situation, it's important to stay up to date with the latest forecast and further warnings are very likely."

The UK Health Security Agency has issued a Level 3 Cold Weather Alert for the whole of England which is likely to be reviewed in the coming days.

Dr Agostinho Sousa, Head of Extreme Events and Health Protection at the UK Health Security Agency, said: "During periods like this, it is important to check in on family, friends and relatives who may be more vulnerable to the cold weather, as it can have a serious impact on health. If you have a pre-existing medical condition or are over the age of 65, it is important to try and heat your home to at least 18°C if you can.''

NEWSLETTER: Sign up for CheshireLive email direct to your inbox here

READ NEXT:

Shocking moment huge tree falls onto busy Crewe road in felling blunder

Cheshire West and Chester Council set to spend £6.3m on houses for Ukrainian and Afghan refugees

Ellesmere Port florist shuts up shop due to 'astronomical running costs'

results.title: Weather warning latest with heavy snow heading to Somerset
results.body:
Heavy snow could hit the South West in the next 24 hours and many could wake up to a couple of centimetres of the white stuff tomorrow morning, the Met Office says.

The greatest risk of snow will initially be in the south from later today and early tomorrow (Wednesday, March 8) as mild air gradually moves in from the South West but brings with it snow as it meets the cold air. This risk of snow gradually spreads further north through the latter half of the week and warnings have been issued.

Weather warnings for snow and ice are in place every day for various regions this week, with a 24-hour snow warning in place for Somerset, Devon, Cornwall, Wiltshire, the South East and South Wales from 12am until 11.59pm tomorrow (March 8).

READ MORE: Met Office expects more weather warnings to come amid -15C Arctic blast

Met Office Deputy Chief Meteorologist Steven Keates said: "The impactful weather will continue through the second half of the week as mild air meets cold air with further snow, ice, wind and then rain likely later in the week and into the weekend.

"From Wednesday, the focus of further snow is across parts of southern England and south Wales, with snow likely to lower levels for a time, and many may wake up to a couple of centimetres of snow on Wednesday morning.

"Through Thursday and Friday the snow risk spreads to central and northern areas of the UK, though it's not possible to pick out precise locations regarding who will see the heaviest snowfall. With a developing situation, it's important to stay up to date with the latest forecast and further warnings are very likely."

READ MORE: Met Office Somerset snow forecast - 24-hour timeline for Arctic forecast

The Met Office said: "A period of snow is likely to cause some travel disruption during Wednesday."

There is a small chance of travel delays on roads with stranded vehicles and passengers, along with delayed or cancelled rail and air travel. There is a chance that some rural communities could be cut off and the potential for power cuts.

A number of towns and villages across Somerset are forecast to see heavy snow, and it's expected from 5pm until 10pm in Yeovil and Taunton tomorrow.

By Friday, winds will also be increasing as low pressure moves in from the west. It remains uncertain where the boundary between the mild air to the south and cold air to the north will lie exactly, but southern areas are more likely to see cloud, wind and rain, while areas to the north of that boundary could see further disruptive snowfall, with strong winds possibly creating snowdrifts in places.

Met Office five-day forecast for the South West

Today: Cloudy on Tuesday with outbreaks of rain and sleet, perhaps some snow, especially over hills. This gradually moves its way southwards, turning patchier and lighter though staying rather cloudy. Feeling cold. Maximum temperature 7 °C.

Tonight: Outbreaks of rain, sleet and snow likely to spread northeastwards overnight, with some lying snow likely by dawn, especially over higher ground. Cold with the risk of icy patches. Minimum temperature -1 °C.

Wednesday: Mostly cloudy with further outbreaks of mainly light rain, sleet, or snow during the morning. Briefly turning drier before rain or snow returns later with strengthening winds. Maximum temperature 6 °C.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday: Turning milder later in the week though staying unsettled with further rain at times and often rather windy, with some strong winds on Friday. A slight improvement on Saturday.

UK long range forecast

March 11-20

Confidence in the details are low throughout this period. On Saturday, cold conditions are expected across the north, accompanied by showers, some of these possibly wintry, although some sunny spells are possible. Elsewhere, milder, cloudier conditions are likely, with outbreaks of rain and some stronger winds possible. There is a small chance of more disruptive snowfall, particularly along the northern edge of the rain band. Into next week, milder conditions are expected to spread northeastwards, bringing rain and stronger winds, as well as some snow along the leading edges. Towards the end of the period, this transition is expected to continue, bringing more unsettled conditions. Periods of snow remain possible, particularly in the far north. Generally becoming somewhat milder through this period, but colder conditions may linger in the north.

March 21-April 4

Confidence remains fairly low during this period. It's likely to be drier further north apart from occasional wintry showers, while rain and strong winds are more likely in the south, with a lower risk of snow at times. These milder conditions may extend north periodically, but it's possible that the cold but bright weather could return south to all parts through late March, bringing a return to drier conditions to the south. Overall, a greater than normal chance of colder spells of weather, especially in the north.

results.title: When and where snow will hit as Met Office issues weather warning
results.body:
Warnings for snow and ice have been issued for up to four days across the country.

The first of four yellow weather warnings are in place today across northeastern parts of the UK. The Met Office reports that as well as some Northern Ireland and southern and central areas of England and Wales, snow and ice is expected.

While a yellow warning for snow comes into place in the north west and Liverpool on Thursday, March 9 and Friday, March 10. The warning means that heavy snow has the potential to cause "significant" disruption on those days, according to forecasters.

READ MORE: Millions of dog owners hit with urgent warning from RSPCA

Snow appears on the forecast from 9am on Thursday in Liverpool and will continue throughout the day. Sleet and snow will clear later on Friday, with it expected to turn less cold by Saturday.

Met Office Chief Meteorologist Dan Suri said: "Snow, ice and low temperatures are the main themes of this week's forecast, as the UK comes under the influence of an arctic maritime airmass as cold air moves in from the north.

"Snow is already falling in parts of the north where some travel disruption likely, as well as a chance of some rural communities being cut off. Snow showers will continue through today and Tuesday here, and Northern Ireland will also be subject to some snow showers, especially over high ground.

"Ice will provide an additional hazard for many with overnight low temperatures well below 0°C for many. Further south wintry hazards will develop with parts of England and Wales affected by icy patches and snow in places tonight and likely further snow in parts of the south early Wednesday."

READ NEXT: Live court updates as Thomas Cashman trial over Olivia Pratt-Korbel murder begins

Man who stabbed his mum in pub car park cleared of murder

Thomas Cashman to claim gunman who killed Olivia Pratt-Korbel 'wasn't me', jury told

Matalan shoppers praise 'beautiful' £9.50 storage baskets that 'look expensive'
